bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 2, 1941

div1.p: Hench is anxious to discuss his questions with Kean.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 2, 1941
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
May 2, 1941
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
General J. R. Kean
2804 “N” St. N.W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I leave today for the meetings in Atlantic City, address Chalfonte-
Haddon Hall from Sunday to Wednesday night. I had hoped to see Dr. Howard Kelly enroute
and to save next Thursday and Friday for Washington, but Dr. Kelly will be away this
week-end. According to my present plan, I will leave Atlantic City Wednesday about
supper time for Baltimore, spend all Thursday morning with Dr. Howard Kelly, see his
yellow fever material, and come to Washington probably after lunch Thursday. I have
many questions to ask you and have them all written down so that we can cover matters
as rapidly as possible. Would it be possible for you to see me Thursday afternoon?
Would you prefer to continue our discussion Thursday evening and get it over with, or
would you prefer to rest in the evening and have me return the next morning if necessary?
I hope to spend at least part of Friday, as much of the day as possible, part of it in
the Congressional Library and perhaps a visit to the office of the Chief of the Signal
Corps to see if I can find some old photographs and also visit the General Staff Map
Collection of the War Department. General Truby suggested that I might find in the
latter the 1899 map and the 1900 map of Camp Columbia as well as the lost key to the
1902 map. I tried to get these through Chief Clerk Freer, I think in the Adjutant
General's department, but they were not to be found. I would appreciate it if you
would be able to tell me how to contact these two departments, the Signal Corps, and
the Map Collection, sometime next Friday.

Last night I reviewed our entire correspondence so that this time we
could finish a lot of unfinished business while we have a secretary to help us. Will
you please contact the girl in the office of the Military Surgeon, to see if she could
be available either for Thursday afternoon (and evening?) or for Friday morning. If
she is not available Thursday afternoon, perhaps I can go to the Signal Corps and Map
Collection then, and we might get her Friday morning or afternoon at your home. Lest
she might not be available, I am writing a brief note to my friends, Dr. Darrell Crain
and Dr. Wallace Yater, to see if they know of someone who might be available, but I
will make no definite arrangements with their secretaries until I hear from you.

Five things that I am particularly anxious to discuss are; (1) the
additional letters from Reed which you have; (2) the “little bundle of retained papers”
which you said you had in your personal file of correspondence and which you thought
we might be able to find; (3) the data which you just received from the files of the
Military Surgeon; (4) Dr. Goldberger's reference which you mentioned--I have not been
able to find it; (5) the copies of the contracts which you said Colonel Siler was making
for me. I shall also get the key to my tin box.

I should most appreciate help in getting the address of Mrs. Ames? and the
address of Dr. Carroll's survivors. I wrote the Pension Bureau and they have the address
of the Carroll family but would not give it to me. They presumably forwarded my letter
but I never received a reply. I am so anxious to find this out as I hope to visit them
sometime with the vague idea that we might find some of Reed's records and Lazear's
General J. R. Kean - 2 - May 2, 1941
notebook which the relatives may have, in complete ignorance of the fact that
perhaps they shouldn't have had them.

You mention that you were going to discuss my plans for memorializing
Camp Lazear with General Ireland. I wondered whether you had had a chance to do
so. General Truby suggested that when I was in Washington I should try to find the
“Medical History of the Post” which he says should be somewhere and contains invaluable
information. He also says that the Q.M.G.O., which I suppose is the Quartermaster
General's Office, should have the plans of Buildings 1 and 2, and he thought it
important for me to find it in order to cancel out the error in the locations of
the stove pipe as apparently erroneously given in Agramonte's drawing. I realize
that in the present state of a national emergency, as you have said, most of these
departments are working overtime. I certainly don't want to be a burden to any
of them, but I gather from my experience to date that most of these departments
have pretty efficient chief clerks who, with the help of their efficient indices
can find an amazing amount of material without much trouble. At least I might
contact some of these men and at their leisure (if any) in the coming weeks or
months, they might be able to find what I want without much trouble. Any help or
advice that you give me will be most gratefully received and if you wish to address
me I shall be at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall. I have written for reservations at
the Mayflower Hotel while I am in Washington.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, PS Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
